channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description: “Our current predicament [in the U. S.] must be understood within the context of minority rule…” https://t.co/dX75hr1YP2

@vhsvvitch The New Yorker excerpted Kael's review of Godfather (#1) recently in a podcast. What writing! The longer version on their website is also a powerhouse. She wrote a dazzling and damning review of John Wayne's "The Cowboys" movie, I recall. Start at 0:50. https://t.co/uwGSLyFUsJ
@juliacarriew Looks like they make an hour version that radio stations can add to their schedule and they also break it up into a few podcasts as well.

I'd be pleased to buy writer @AdamLiptak a cup of coffee if I could ask whether the reporting hints at any influence of money in this NY policy. For-profit prisons, and maybe prisons others too, like to have full rosters and paying customers. https://t.co/z0a9fXhtE0

1/5 Dad worked for the natural gas company. Once in a while I’d hear him talk about a number called degree days, which comes from a formula that includes the mean monthly temperature.
2/5 The number of degree days for the town every March for the last decade gives a clue to how much gas the company should have on hand to sell next March.
3/5 But they’d need an extra, buffer supply of gas, because next March might be colder than other recent years. Each March has its own unpredictable degree day total, when all is said and done.
4/5 Our local natural gas company stored gas reserves in a porous layer of rock beneath the north side of the metro area. Buy it cheap in the summer, pump it underground, and pump it out later when it's needed.
5/5 Folks want their houses at 65 F. If the average March temperature is 40, that’s thirty days with a 25 degree heating load. If the average temperature is 15, that’s thirty days with a 50 degree heating load. We start to see why the gas company thinks in terms of degree days.
The National Weather Service explains the actual calculation of degree days for both cooling and heating.
https://t.co/V2XCknFYT8
Lots of us quote famous people on Twitter. After quoting the hot shots, what comes next? https://t.co/PxHudDY3wp https://t.co/gSjTT2JQuV

3/3 Folks want their houses at 65 F. If the average March temperature is 40, that’s thirty days with a 25 degree heating load. If the average temperature is 15, that’s thirty days with a 50 degree heating load. We start to see why the gas company thinks in terms of degree days.

1/3 Dad worked for the natural gas company. Once in a while I’d hear him talk about a number called degree days. The average hourly temperature in the town every March for the last decade gives a clue to how much gas they should have on hand to sell next March.
2/3 But they’d need a extra, buffer supply of gas, because next March might be colder than the ten-year average. Each March has its own degree day total, when all is said and done.

The History of Rock Music in 500 Songs podcast has more than 140 episodes now, one per song, and still progressing… https://t.co/8aFCFkcNNL
The Beatles & “Love Me Do” episode. https://t.co/BkGlxaVeCu
“Democracy has to be born anew every generation, and education is its midwife.” --John Dewey (1916)
"Readers, too, need to be at the heart of the conversation, and much more engaged than print allows." From the launch of the @Guardian's Comment is free site in 2006. https://t.co/mE7oo7qTQl
Lots of action at the bird feeder this morning, even one redwing blackbird, a bird I associate with country roads running between Midwestern farm fields, not with our small-city neighborhoods.
I was skimming a 1960 article in a Soviet anthropology journal and noticed how positively the word “propaganda” is used in its pages. I assume there’s a paper trail that explains that…

Some mornings you open your eyes to eye-opening sentences and images on FB. “Pollution makes great sunsets.” “…like a true addict, I wanted all of my recovery to come at once.” “We stopped in Belize and visited a toucan sanctuary. It was my favorite part of the trip.” https://t.co/5f87QZEsGb
@elizmccracken I’ve added the ending of Dreamsong 282 to my repertoire, but mostly to say to myself. https://t.co/uhfWeukI37
@HormoneHangover @PYeerk I thought the Science Friday radio show was talking in very fuzzy, nearly un-pin-down-able ways about that term in last week's show.
"Americans, by and large, are putting the pandemic behind them." (Privilege makes that possible.) See also: Racism, putting behind them; Poverty, putting behind them; Etc. https://t.co/3Niceb2AyO

Should Poem A and Poem B be added to the book manuscript? Each one is only six lines long. You can read them in this thread below. Merci.
Poem A https://t.co/FnRoaNdkGQ
Poem B https://t.co/Cz5yOaqXeR

A tweet got mucho readers, then @Twitter’s algo had Twitter’s brain ask me to sign up for the professional Twitter thing. I tried to see what in the world that actually means but the explanation web page neglected to explain. Bye, T-brain. Billing you for ten minutes of my life.
@toebean_peets Just living life as a go-between…
RSS feed updates sports scores on @WatchfireSigns digital billboards. https://t.co/wWv9r844DF https://t.co/LGP4IrUHDG
Getting started here in our section of South Bend, Indiana. https://t.co/i4pMojM5tz

Responsibility to renewable systems would be a satisfying and enduring cultural story much better than our current one, which glorifies the frantic and ecstatic strip-mining of the planet’s resources, crashing the natural systems that make the resources in the first place.
